question.title: How to create an instance of enum using reflection in java?

node.contents: You could create an enum class on-the-fly using bytecode generation. But in that case, the enum wouldn't exist at compile-time, so you wouldn't be able to refer to it in the rest of your code (you'd only be able to access it via reflection, which is a run-time and not a compile-time mechanism).

astNode.text: You could create an enum class on-the-fly using bytecode generation. But in that case, the enum wouldn't exist at compile-time, so you wouldn't be able to refer to it in the rest of your code (you'd only be able to access it via reflection, which is a run-time and not a compile-time mechanism).

node.contents: When I'm reading the "effective java", author told me that a single-element enum type is the best way to implement a singleton, because we don't have to consider sophisticated serialization or reflection attacks. This means we cannot create an instance of enum using reflection, is this right? I have done some test, an enum class here:

This means we cannot create an instance of enum using reflection, is this right? I have done some test, an enum class here:

node.contents: Then I tried to create an instance of Weekday:

astNode.text: Then I tried to create an instance of Weekday:

elements.contents: Class<Weekday> weekdayClass = Weekday.class; Constructor<Weekday> cw = weekdayClass.getConstructor(null); cw.setAccessible(true); cw.newInstance(null);

units.rawText: Class<Weekday> weekdayClass = Weekday.class; Constructor<Weekday> cw = weekdayClass.getConstructor(null); cwsetAccessible(true); cwnewInstance(null);

node.contents: As you know, it doesn't work. When I change the key word "enum" to "class", it works. I want to know why. Thank you pre.

astNode.text: As you know, it doesn't work. When I change the key word "enum" to "class", it works. I want to know why. Thank you pre.

node.contents: The `enum` is actually compiled into a `final class` that extends `java.lang.Enum` with a `private` constructor, and that does not actually prevent reflection instantiation if `setAccessible(true);` is called. I'm still wondering how is that prevented?

astNode.text: The `enum` is actually compiled into a `final class` that extends `java.lang.Enum` with a `private` constructor, and that does not actually prevent reflection instantiation if `setAccessible(true);` is called. I'm still wondering how is that prevented?

node.contents: This is built into the language. From the Java Language Specification (§8.9):

astNode.text: This is built into the language. From the Java Language Specification (§8.9):

node.contents: It is a compile-time error to attempt to explicitly instantiate an enum type (§15.9.1). The final clone method in Enum ensures that enum constants can never be cloned, and the special treatment by the serialization mechanism ensures that duplicate instances are never created as a result of deserialization. Reflective instantiation of enum types is prohibited. Together, these four things ensure that no instances of an enum type exist beyond those defined by the enum constants.

astNode.text: It is a compile-time error to attempt to explicitly instantiate an enum type (§15.9.1). The final clone method in Enum ensures that enum constants can never be cloned, and the special treatment by the serialization mechanism ensures that duplicate instances are never created as a result of deserialization. Reflective instantiation of enum types is prohibited. Together, these four things ensure that no instances of an enum type exist beyond those defined by the enum constants.

node.contents: The whole purpose of this is to allow the safe use of == to compare Enum instances.

astNode.text: The whole purpose of this is to allow the safe use of == to compare Enum instances.

node.contents: Enums has been designed to be treated as constant objects. It overrides readObject and throws invalid object exception to prevent default serialization. Also it overrides clone() and throws clone not supported exception. As far as reflection is concerned, the constructor of Enum is protected.So if you use above code it will throw NoSuchMethodFound.

astNode.text: Enums has been designed to be treated as constant objects. It overrides readObject and throws invalid object exception to prevent default serialization. Also it overrides clone() and throws clone not supported exception. As far as reflection is concerned, the constructor of Enum is protected.So if you use above code it will throw NoSuchMethodFound.

node.contents: Even if you use getDeclaredConstructor() instead of getConstructor, you should get the same exception. I assume its been restricted through SecurityManager in java.

astNode.text: Even if you use getDeclaredConstructor() instead of getConstructor, you should get the same exception. I assume its been restricted through SecurityManager in java.

node.contents: It is correct that new instances of an enum class cannot be created retro-actively, not even with reflection.

astNode.text: It is correct that new instances of an enum class cannot be created retro-actively, not even with reflection.

elements.contents: val weekdayClass = classOf[Weekday] val weekdayConstructor = weekdayClass getDeclaredConstructor (classOf[String], classOf[Int]) weekdayConstructor setAccessible true weekdayConstructor newInstance ("", Integer.valueOf(0))

units.rawText: val weekdayClass = classOf[Weekday] val weekdayConstructor = weekdayClass getDeclaredConstructor (classOf[String], classOf[Int]) weekdayConstructor setAccessible true weekdayConstructor newInstance ("", IntegervalueOf(0))

node.contents: Usually, this should work. But in the case of enums, this is special-cased in Constructor#newInstance:

astNode.text: Usually, this should work. But in the case of enums, this is special-cased in Constructor#newInstance:

elements.contents: if ((clazz.getModifiers() & Modifier.ENUM) != 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot reflectively create enum objects");

units.rawText: if ((clazz.getModifiers() & Modifier.ENUM) != 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot reflectively create enum objects");

node.contents: Thus, we receive the following exception when trying to instantiate a new enum instance:

astNode.text: Thus, we receive the following exception when trying to instantiate a new enum instance:

elements.contents: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Cannot reflectively create enum objects at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:520) ...

units.rawText: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Cannot reflectively create enum objects at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:520)...

node.contents: I assume that the last approach (which will probably be successful, because no checks or constructors are run) involves sun.misc.Unsafe#allocateInstance.

astNode.text: I assume that the last approach (which will probably be successful, because no checks or constructors are run) involves sun.misc.Unsafe#allocateInstance.

node.contents: So if your objective is to persistent and then reconstructed the enum information. You will need to persist the enumClassName and its value.

astNode.text: So if your objective is to persistent and then reconstructed the enum information. You will need to persist the enumClassName and its value.

elements.contents: public enum DaysOfWeek{ Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat, Sun } DaysOfWeek dow = DaysOfWeek.Tue; String value = dow.toString(); String enumClassName = dow.getClass().getName(); // Persist value and enumClassName // ... // Reconstitute the data Class clz = Class.forName(enumClassName); Object o = Enum.valueOf(clz, value); DaysOfWeek dow2 = (DaysOfWeek)o; System.out.println(dow2);

comments.text: // Persist value and enumClassName // ... // Reconstitute the data Class clz = Class.forName(enumClassName); Object o = Enum.valueOf(clz, value); DaysOfWeek dow2 = (DaysOfWeek)o; System.out.println(dow2);

units.rawText: public enum DaysOfWeek{ } DaysOfWeek dow = DaysOfWeek.Tue; String value = dow.toString(); String enumClassName = dow.getClass().getName(); // Persist value and enumClassName // ... // Reconstitute the data Class clz = Class.forName(enumClassName); Object o = Enum.valueOf(clz, value); DaysOfWeek dow2 = (DaysOfWeek)o; System.out.println(dow2);
